Award.AwardTitle: Direct and Indirect Impacts of Credit Scoring for Small and Medium Enterprises

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
Proposal Title: Direct and Indirect Impacts of Credit Scoring for Small and Medium Enterprises
Proposal Number: SES - 1326433
Principal Investigator: Dean Karlan

Lack of access to finance remains one of the core challenges to small firm growth in low- and middle-income countries. Many small and medium enterprises (SMEs) have high returns to capital but if banks cannot identify these borrowers, they may restrict lending or misallocate funds, limiting production and employment growth. Many low- and middle-income countries do not have credit bureaus or other effective public systems that aggregate information valuable for screening, further exacerbating the challenge of identifying high return borrowers.

While a lack of adequate financing may constrain the expansion of individual firms, the provision of credit to a single business is likely to have spillover effects on other firms and on consumers. Firms operate in a web of competitors and suppliers, and these businesses will also be affected by credit that is provided to a single loan recipient. For example, standard economic theory suggests that competitor firms will see decreased demand when competitors gain access to credit. At the same time, increased demand for supplier inputs can lead to increased upstream profitability. Classic theories of economic development stress the importance of these linkages in the takeoff to development.

This study uses a randomized controlled trial methodology to evaluate the impact of providing credit to SMEs, examining both the direct effects on recipient firms and the indirect spillover effects on competitors and firms linked to treated businesses through supply chains. A large development bank in the Philippines is implementing a new credit scoring system at 45 branches across the country. The new system will process all SME loans and assign a credit score to each loan applicant. Credit scores falling in a certain range below the cut-off for automatic loan approval will be randomly approved or denied. The randomized design generates exogenous variation in access to credit among SME loan applicants, enabling us to measure the impact of credit on firms.

An important and innovative aspect of this evaluation is its focus on spillovers across firms. The project will measure vertical spillovers by surveying firms in the supply chains of loan applicants, and exploit variation in the number of firms receiving credit in different industries and markets to measure horizontal spillovers on firms competing directly with treatment and control businesses. Identifying competitor and supply chain markets and the horizontal and vertical interactions of sample firms constitutes a new approach to the study of firms in low- and middle-income countries. The findings are highly policy relevant. Evidence that providing credit to one firm has positive market spillovers, perhaps though increasing competition or allowing suppliers to invest more, would provide a strong justification for increasing access to credit. On the other hand, if gains to the firm receiving credit come entirely at the expense of losses to its competitors, then subsidized credit would accomplish little, suggesting that the gains from microcredit may be overestimated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the grant period, Innovations for Poverty Action (IPA) and Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP) finalized, piloted, and launched the electronic credit scoring program for micro and small loan applications. By July 2015, all DBP micro and small loan applicants nationwide must pass the credit scorecard to become eligible for loans. Part of passing the credit scorecard involves random assignment for borderline firms, making possible the randomized controlled trial to evaluate the direct and indirect impacts of SME lending. 

To launch the credit scoring program, IPA and DBP conducted three trainings with Account Officers and regional managers in Manila, Cagayan de Oro, and Cebu, to explain the new credit scoring policies and the role of credit scoring in the application process. Meeting in these three locations made it possible for account officers and regional management from all of the Philippines to attend. 

By mid-2015, IPA finalized the survey instrument, piloted the questionnaire and survey protocol, and finalized all data management procedures. In November 2014, IPA conducted a survey pilot in Manila, Cagayan de Oro, Naga, and Iloilo. IPA trained Field Officers from these four locations and supervised interviews with existing DBP borrowers.

After the credit scoring system went live in June 2015, DBP scored almost 30 businesses; however, most of these applicants had a previous borrowing history with DBP, and DBP was only willing to include new clients in the study. Thus, we were not able to include most of these businesses in the study. 

As of February 2016, eight businesses eligible for the study had been scored. All eight passed via randomization (with >95% chance of passing based on high scores). IPA surveyed four of the eight (with two refusals, one business not found, and one business that had not opened yet). IPA did not survey any competitors as it was unclear at the time whether it would prove practical. For the four businesses surveyed, competitors were either much larger than the respondents or respondents operated unique businesses with no local competitors.  

To increase the number of respondents, DBP began holding SME Finance Forums, inviting SMEs with no history of borrowing from DBP to learn more about DBP loans and consider applying. On October 8, 2015, DBP hosted the first forum in Manila and around 40 businesses attended. Most businesses were interested in applying for loans; however, only five businesses were successfully processed through credit scoring over the next few weeks. DBP claimed many businesses were not ready for loans and had come only for information. They said that of those who did apply, many businesses did not provide enough paperwork to receive a credit score. 

On February 10, 2016, lead PI Dean Karlan, as well as co-PI Pamela Jakiela and IPA Country Director Nassreena Sampaco-Baddiri spoke with DBP Vice President Benel Lagua to discuss the project. The PIs expressed their disappointment in the slow pace of the implementation. Given the challenges being faced by the DBP, it is unlikely that the research project will achieve its sample size goal by end of 2016. The PI team is exploring alternative sites where the aims and objectives of the grant can be pursued in order to complement and add to the lessons and data acquired with DBP.
